verses.verse: {David is Anointed King} {(2 Samuel 5:1-10)} d Later on, all of Israel gathered together at Hebron in order to tell David, "Look, we're your own flesh and blood! {Lit. bone}

Even back when Saul was ruling as king, you kept on leading the army of Israel out to battle {The Heb. lacks out to battle} and bringing them in again. {The Heb. lacks in again} The Lord your God told you, «You yourself will shepherd my people Israel and will be Commander-in-Chief {Lit. Nagid ; i. e. a senior officer entrusted with dual roles of operational oversight and management authority} over my people Israel.»"

So all the elders of Israel approached the king at Hebron, where David entered into a covenant in {Lit. covenant that is, at Hebron in} the presence of the Lord . Then they anointed David to be king over Israel, just as the Lord had sent word through {Lit. word by the hand of} Samuel.
{David Captures Jerusalem} d Later, David and all of Israel marched to Jerusalem (then known as Jebus, where the Jebusites lived when they inhabited the land).
The inhabitants of Jebus told David, "You're not coming in here!" Nevertheless, David captured the fortress of Zion, now known as the city of David.
David had announced, "Whoever first attacks the Jebusites will be appointed chief and commander." When Zeruiah's son Joab went up first, he became chief.
David occupied {Or lived in} the fortress, so it was named the City of David after him.

He built up the walls surrounding the city in a complete circle from the terrace ramparts, {Lit. the Millo , fortified areas of ancient Jerusalem with terraces and retaining walls} and Joab repaired the rest of the city.
David became more and more prestigious because the Lord of the Heavenly Armies was with him.

{David's Elite Soldiers} {(2 Samuel 23:8-17)} d These are the leaders of the elite warriors who were strong supporters of David in his kingdom, along with all of Israel, in keeping with the message from the Lord concerning Israel.

This record of the warriors who were for David included {The Heb. lacks included} Hachmoni's son Jashobeam, {Or Jashobeam son of a Hachmonite ; cf. 2Sam 23:8, where this individual is named Josheb-basshebeth the Tahkemonite} leader of the platoons, {Lit. thirties ; i. e. a military unit roughly analogous to two or more squads; and so throughout the chapter; or a group of distinguished officers who served David; cf. 2Sam 23:8} who killed 300 with his spear in a single encounter.

Next to him among the Three {Lit. the three valiant ones ; i. e. a group of three distinguished officers who served David, and so throughout the chapter; cf. 2Sam 23:8} was Dodo {Cf. 2Sam 23:9, where this individual is named Dodai} the Ahohite's son Eleazar.
He was with David at Pas-dammim when the Philistines were there to engage them in battle. There was a field planted with barley, and the army had run away from the Philistines,
but they took a defensive stand in the middle of the field and killed the Philistines while the Lord saved them by means of a great victory. {Or deliverance}
Later, the Three platoon leaders went down to David's hideout {Lit. rock} at the cave of Adullam when the Philistine army was camping in the valley of giants. {Or the Rephaim Valley}
David was living in that stronghold at the time, while a Philistine garrison was then at Bethlehem.
David expressed a longing, "Oh, how I wish someone would get me a drink of water from the Bethlehem well that's by the city gate!"

So the Three broke through the Philistine ranks, drew some water from the Bethlehem well that was next to the city gate, and brought it back to David. But David refused to drink it, poured it out in the Lord's presence, and

said in response, "May God forbid me to do this! I won't drink the blood of these men, will I? After all, they risked their lives to bring it to me." {The Heb. lacks to me} That's why he wouldn't drink it. The Three warriors did these things.

{David's Other Valiant Soldiers} {(2 Samuel 23:18-39)} d Joab's brother Abishai was the lieutenant {Lit. chief} in charge of the platoons. He used his spear to fight and kill 300 men, gaining a reputation distinct from the Three.
He was more well-known than the Three, {So MT; the Syr reads thirty} but he never attained the stature of the Three.

Jehoiada's son Benaiah, who was a valiant man, accomplished great things. He was from Kabzeel. He killed two men named {The Heb. lacks men named} Ariel from Moab {The Heb. name Ariel means lion} and then he also went down into a pit and struck down a lion during a snow storm one day.

He also killed a soldier {Lit. man} from Egypt of enormous height seven and a half feet {Lit. five cubits} tall. The Egyptian carried a spear comparable in size to a weaver's beam, but Benaiah attacked him with a staff, snatched the spear out of the Egyptian's hand and killed him with his own spear.
Benaiah did things like this and gained a reputation comparable to the Three warriors.
He was well known among the platoons, but he didn't measure up to the Three. {Or never attained the stature of} David placed him in charge of his security detail.
The elite forces included Asahel (Joab's brother), Dodo's son Elhanan from Bethlehem,
Shammoth from Haror, {Or Shammoth from Haror ; also cf. 2Sam 23:25, where he is named Shammah from Harod} Helez the Pelonite, {Cf. 2Sam 23:26, where he is named Helez the Paltite}
Ikkesh's son Ira from Tekoa, Abiezer from Anathoth,
Sibbecai the Hushathite, Ilai the Ahohite,
Maharai from Netophah, Baanah's son Heled from Netophah,
Ribai's son Ithai from Gibeah, controlled by {The Heb. lacks controlled by} the descendants of Benjamin, Benaiah of Pirathon,
Hurai from the wadis {I. e. seasonal streams or rivers that channel water during rain seasons but are dry at other times} of Gaash, Abiel the Arbathite,
Azmaveth from Baharum, Eliahba from Shaalbon,
Hashem the Gizonite, Shagee the Hararite's son Jonathan,
Sachar the Hararite's son Ahiam, Ur's son Eliphal,
Hepher the Mecherathite, Ahijah the Pelonite,
Hezro from Carmel, Ezbai's son Naarai,
Joel (Nathan's brother), Hagri's son Mibhar,
Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai from Beeroth, who was the armor-bearer for Zeruiah's son Joab,
Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
Uriah the Hittite, Ahlai's son Zabad,
Shiza the Reubenite's son Adina, a leader of the descendants of Reuben, along with thirty others with him,
Maacah's son Hanan, Joshaphat the Mithnite,
Uzzia the Ashterathite, Hotham the Aroerite's sons Shama and Jeiel,
Shimri's son Jediael and his brother Joha the Tizite,
Eliel the Mahavite, Elnaam's sons Jeribai and Joshaviah, Ithmah the Moabite,
Eliel, Obed, and Jaasiel the Mezobaite.
